title: 107_s156
content: The "After School Education and Anti-Crime Act of 2001" aims to improve academic and social outcomes for students, reduce juvenile crime, and decrease the risk of youth becoming victims of crime by providing productive activities during after school hours. Congress finds that today's youth face increased social risks, spend more time unsupervised, and are most at risk of violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are more severe in 2001. Many states have shown the benefits of after school programs. Law enforcement data indicates that youth aged 12-17 are most vulnerable to violence between 3 p.m. and 6 p.m. Academic failure consequences are more severe in 2001. After school programs in many states help address social issues like drugs, alcohol, and gangs. Governors support increasing after school programs through a Federal/State partnership. Leading police chiefs also endorse this initiative. Many governors and law enforcement officials support increasing after school programs to address social issues like drugs, alcohol, and gangs among youth. Leading police chiefs and prosecutors advocate for programs that offer recreation, academic support, and community involvement. Sheriffs, prosecutors, and police organizations representing 360,000 officers are urging public officials to provide after school programs for school-age children and teens in the United States, emphasizing the importance of safe and positive learning environments during those hours. The Act aims to enhance students' academic success, create safe after-school environments, offer alternatives to negative activities, and reduce juvenile crime. It amends the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act to increase program authorization from 3 to 5. The Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include various stakeholders in the program and require recipients to provide a minimum of 35% of the project's annual cost from sources other than government funds. The Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to require recipients to provide 35% of the project's annual cost from non-government sources. The recipient must contribute in cash or in kind, evaluated fairly, not exceeding 25% of the project's annual cost from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs. Additionally, the recipient must maintain their fiscal effort from non-Federal sources each year. The recipient must contribute up to 25% of the project's annual cost from funds provided by the Secretary under other Federal programs and maintain their fiscal effort from non-Federal sources each year. SEC. 7. USES OF FUNDS. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to allow grants for establishing or expanding community learning centers that provide various activities, including job skills preparation and after school programs with specific requirements. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include after school programs that offer mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, and technology training, as well as drug, alcohol, and gang prevention. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include after school programs providing mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation. At least 2/3 of the funds appropriated under section 10907 each fiscal year must be used for these programs. The 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include after school programs offering mentoring, academic assistance, recreational activities, technology training, drug, alcohol, and gang prevention activities, health and nutrition counseling, and job skills preparation. At least 2/3 of the funds appropriated under section 10907 each fiscal year must be used for these programs. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATION. Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act is amended to include provisions for local educational agencies, schools, or consortia to involve volunteers from various communities, ensure youth participation in designing after-school activities, and use creative outreach methods. The amended Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act encourages involvement of volunteers from communities, youth participation in activity design, creative outreach methods, donation requests for equipment, and collaboration with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. The amended Section 10905 of the 21st Century Community Learning Centers Act encourages youth involvement, volunteer participation, creative outreach methods, donation requests for equipment, and collaboration with park and recreation agencies to avoid duplication of activities. SEC. 9. Community Learning Center defined as including law enforcement organizations like the Police Athletic and Activity League. SEC. 10. Authorization of appropriations increased to $1,000,000,000 for fiscal year 2002 and gradually increasing to $1,500,000,000 for fiscal year 2006. SEC. 11. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act and its amendments will be effective on October 1, 2001.
